Key Match Events: Anthony Volpe hit a grand slam home run in the third inning
Freddie Freeman hit a two-run home run in the first inning
Post-Match Reflections: Aaron Judge expressed pride in the team's resilience after the comeback win
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game was played in New York
Others: The Yankees moved closer to getting swept in the World Series before Volpe's grand slam
The Yankees broke open the game with a five-run eighth
Austin Wells and Gleyber Torres added homers for the Yankees
New York, which had scored just seven runs in the first three games, had some of its swagger back
Fans in the sellout crowd of 49,354 chanted Volpe's name during the ninth inning
Freddie Freeman homered for his sixth consecutive Series game
Los Angeles Dodgers' Freddie Freeman celebrated his two-run home run with a trot around the bases
Game 5 is Wednesday night, with the Yankees ace Gerrit Cole and the Dodgers’ Jack Flaherty meeting in a rematch of Game 1
Seeking to become the first team to overcome a 3-0 Series deficit, New York surged ahead 5-2
Twenty-one of the previous 24 teams to take 3-0 Series leads went on to sweeps
The 2004 Boston Red Sox, sparked by a stolen base by Dave Roberts, are the only team to overcome a 3-0 deficit in any round
Judge drove in his first run of the Series with an RBI single in the eighth
Dodgers sensation Shohei Ohtani also is 2 for 15 after going 1 for 4 with a single
Volpe was interviewed after the game by former Yankees captain Derek Jeter, now a Fox broadcaster
Former Boston star David Ortiz, also a Fox commentator, gave Volpe a shirt
Others (continued): Volpe was 8 when the Yankees last won the Series
Volpe scored New York's first run when he walked after falling behind 0-2 in the second inning
He made a baserunning blunder when he headed back to second to tag up and failed to score on Wells’ double off the center-field wall — pounding his own leg in anger
Verdugo followed with an RBI grounder
Los Angeles closed within 6-4 in a two-run fifth that included Will Smith's homer off Gil and an RBI grounder by Freeman
Despite a sprained right ankle, Freeman beat a relay to avoid an inning-ending double play on what originally was ruled an out but was reversed in a video review
New York stopped a seven-game Series losing streak against the Dodgers dating to 1981
The Yankees got their first seven RBIs from the bottom three hitters in their batting order, Volpe, Wells and Verdugo, who had entered 4 for 32 with three RBIs in the Series
Volpe was interviewed after the game by former Yankees captain Derek Jeter, now a Fox broadcaster
Former Boston star David Ortiz, also a Fox commentator, gave Volpe a shirt
